Poorly Staffed.  RN's aren't paid well, and once you're in the raises don't keep up with cost of living. So basically RN's who worked at the hospital for years & left because they were sick of being underpaid didn't get the raise they deserve.    Any job you apply to that should be a "raise" within spectrum bases that raise on your current rate, not on what the job should pay. You're a dime a dozen, if you won't take the job for little pay, they will find someone to do it for that low amount.  Working here is basically a dead-end job.  They care more about how things are "perceived" by the patient that they do about the actual quality of the care that gets delivered.  If you gave corporate the option of "doing the right thing for the patient vs doing something that makes the patient THINK they are getting the right thing"... they would totally go for the latter.  Especially if it saves money.  They prey on the fact that a lot of nurses are caring types who martyr themselves and do a lot of "cool" "Intense" jobs for actual passion for their jobs or for bragging rights- but they don't compensate for the hard work RN's do

Some individual managers are good, some are a joke.  Depends on the individuals.  The manager evals go from the top down, not at all from the bottom up.  There's no way to give feedback on your manager's performance... which shows that they only care about "the numbers" and how things are going on paper.  Meanwhile, the staff on the front line can actually identify a lot of waste and inefficiency in their manager but have no way to voice it without giving themselves away & putting themselves at risk for retaliation.
